title: ‘Speak, Silence’ Review: The Mystery of W.G. Sebald
sub_head: The German writer was a master of a hybrid of fiction and nonfiction, informed by imagination and observation.
body:
On the second page of “Speak, Silence: In Search of W.G. Sebald,” Carole Angier reveals that her subject’s work first attracted her because he “was the German writer who most deeply took on the burden of German responsibility for the Holocaust.” Was he?
Born in 1944 in the Allgäu region in the Bavarian Alps, Winfried Georg Sebald left his native land when still a young man. He settled in England, where he taught at the Universities of Manchester and, for many years, East Anglia. He wore a drooping moustache and loved walking, swimming, nature and his dogs. He died in a car accident near his Norwich home in 2001 at the age of 57.
